cards.title: UK wakes up to ‘freeze of the century’ with warnings snow is on the way
cards.abstract: UK wakes up to ‘freeze of the century’ with warnings snow is on the way

slides.body:
Brits woke up to biting temperatures this morning, as Scandinavia’s ‘freeze of the century’ moves in.
The Met Office issued a yellow ice alert for London and the south east lasting until 10am, with warnings of sleet, snow and ice and plummeting temperatures (Picture: Andrew McCaren/LNP)

image.title: UK wakes up to ‘freeze of the century’ with warnings snow is on the way
image.caption:
Brits woke up to biting temperatures this morning, as Scandinavia’s ‘freeze of the century’ moves in.
The Met Office issued a yellow ice alert for London and the south east lasting until 10am, with warnings of sleet, snow and ice and plummeting temperatures (Picture: Andrew McCaren/LNP)

slides.body: It comes after forecasters predicted a cold spell across the country coming from Scandinavia that is due to last until at least Friday this week. Norway’s weather service said it recorded the coldest temperature seen in the country in 25 years last Friday. One village in Lapland, pictured, recorded -43.5°C (Picture: Getty Images)

subCards.title: Macron appoints France's youngest ever prime minister
subCards.abstract: Emmanuel Macron has appointed France's youngest ever prime minister - and the first to be gay.

images.title: Gabriel Attal will be France's prime minister. Pic: Tom Nicholson/Shutterstock
images.caption: Gabriel Attal will be France's prime minister. Pic: Tom Nicholson/Shutterstock

highlights.text:
**New prime minister**: Emmanuel Macron has appointed Gabriel Attal, 34, as France's youngest and first openly gay prime minister. He replaces Elisabeth Borne, who resigned after a turbulent term.

**Popular figure**: Gabriel Attal is a popular politician who served as government spokesperson and education minister. He is seen as a savvy and clear communicator who can revitalise Macron's camp ahead of the European elections.

**Opposition criticism**: The appointment of Attal is dismissed by opposition leaders as a desperate move by Macron to cling to his popularity. They say it will not change his unpopular policies on pensions, immigration and other issues.

subCards.title: Golden Globe-winning actor spotted celebrating win with burger and fries
subCards.abstract: Paul Giamatti was pictured celebrating his Golden Globes win with a burger and chips – while still wearing his dinner jacket. The Holdovers actor was snapped holding off on the decadent, champagne-fuelled after-parties in favour of a California fast-food restaurant. Giamatti and his girlfriend Clara Wong, who was still in her gown, were pictured en...

images.title: Paul Giamatti and Clara Wong were seen tucking into their burgers in black tie
images.caption: Paul Giamatti and Clara Wong were seen tucking into their burgers in black tie

highlights.text:
**Giamatti's Golden Globe win**

- Paul Giamatti won the Best Actor in a Comedy award at the Golden Globes for his role in The Holdovers.
- He celebrated with his girlfriend Clara Wong and his team at an In-N-Out restaurant, where he enjoyed a "double-double" burger and chips.
- He later attended two parties in Beverly Hills hosted by his agency and NBC Universal.

**Giamatti's career highlights**

- Giamatti has been acting for 33 years since his debut in Past Midnight in 1991.
- He starred in Saving Private Ryan, American Splendor, Sideways, John Adams and Barney's Version, among other films and TV shows.
- He has won two Golden Globes and an Emmy for his performances.

subCards.title: Tube strikes: Aslef drivers to be balloted on possible walkout amid Sadiq Khan 'money train' deal row
subCards.abstract: Tube strikes: Aslef drivers to be balloted on possible walkout amid Sadiq Khan 'money train' deal row - Exclusive: Aslef to re-ballot its 2,000 members to enable it to retain power to call strike at fortnight’s notice

images.title: tube strikes
images.caption: tube strikes

highlights.text:
The article reports on the potential ***Tube strike action*** by Aslef drivers over pay negotiations with Transport for London (TfL). It:

- Explains how the mayor of London, **Sadiq Khan**, unexpectedly secured an extra **£30m** from City Hall to boost the annual pay rise for **16,000 Tube staff** - a move that led the RMT union to suspend its planned strike until Friday.
- Describes how Aslef, which represents most Tube drivers, is about to re-ballot its **2,000 members** to enable it to retain the power to call a strike at a fortnight's notice, after accepting a **five per cent** offer.
- Highlights the demands of Aslef for a **12 per cent** rise and a further increase for the **2024/25** year, matching the RPI rate of interest in February last year when the pay talks began.
- Quotes the criticism of the mayor's intervention by the **City Hall Conservatives** transport spokesman, who accused him of throwing money at the RMT to save his political skin and undermining TfL management and its industrial relations strategy.
- Mentioned the warning by the **TSSA union** that its members are also ready to ballot for strike action over pay, and the confusion about how to proceed with the talks involving all Tube unions this week.
- Ended with the mayor's spokesperson defending his decision to offer the extra money to avert a week of strike action and stressing the importance of negotiation and talking with workers.

subCards.title: Donald Trump claims presidential immunity in seeking to dismiss election interference case
subCards.abstract: Donald Trump will go to court today in an effort to block one of his criminal trials.

images.title: Donald Trump speaks during a campaign event in Clinton, Iowa
images.caption: Donald Trump speaks during a campaign event in Clinton, Iowa

highlights.text:
**Trump's appeal hearing in Washington DC**

- Trump is trying to block one of his four criminal trials related to election interference and the Capitol riot.
- He claims he has immunity as a former president and that his speech was protected by the First Amendment.
- A lower court judge has already rejected his arguments and set a trial date for March 4.

**Trump's motion to dismiss charges in Georgia**

- Trump is also facing racketeering and conspiracy charges in Georgia for pressuring election officials to overturn the results.
- He filed a motion to dismiss the charges, citing immunity, due process and double jeopardy.
- Prosecutors say he was acting beyond his official duties and that he was not impeached on the same charges by the Senate.

subCards.title: Channel 4 in diversity row over white bosses
subCards.abstract: Channel 4 has launched a protest against the appointment of four white directors to its board in a row over ethnic diversity. Lucy Frazer, the Culture Secretary, on Monday approved the appointment of five new non-executive directors to join the broadcaster’s board, four of whom are white. The move sparked criticism from Sir Ian Cheshire, the chairm...

images.title: channel 4 board
images.caption: New board members L-R Dame Annette King, Debbie Wosskow OBE, Sebastian James and Alex Burford - Bloomberg/Campaign Live/LinkedIn

topQuestions.q: How will the new board members affect Channel 4's diversity strategy and targets?
Why did Lucy Frazer approve four white directors despite Sir Ian Cheshire's criticism?

highlights.text: The article reports on the ***diversity row*** over the appointment of **four white directors** to Channel 4's board, approved by Culture Secretary *Lucy Frazer*. The move sparked criticism from **Sir Ian Cheshire**, the chairman of Channel 4, who said the board was **lagging behind its own diversity targets** and that he was committed to **pushing for further progress**. The new board members include **Boots chief executive Sebastian James**, **advertising industry veteran Dame Annette King**, **Warner Records UK boss Alex Burford** and **entrepreneur Debbie Wosskow**. The only non-white appointment is **Tom Adeyoola**, a tech entrepreneur and board governor. The diversity row comes as Channel 4 faces a **deep advertising downturn** and plans to **slash up to 200 roles** as it shifts its focus to **streaming and social media channels**.

cards.title: Tesco announces major boost for every Clubcard shopper
cards.abstract: Get more from your money this January.

images.title: Illustrative image of a Tesco Clubcard
images.caption: Clubcards at the ready (Picture: Getty)

highlights.text: ***Tesco*** has announced that customers will get **double Clubcard points** when they shop over the next **seven weeks**, until **February 25**. To get the double points, customers just need to **scan their Clubcard** when paying for groceries, online, or at petrol stations, or **link their card to their Tesco account**. They will then receive **Tesco vouchers** in their next two statements, or they can redeem them **instantly** online or via the app. A staggering **10 billion Clubcard points** are expected to be collected, benefiting more than **20 million members**. The offer is **excluded** from Tesco Bank, Tesco Mobile, Tesco Photo, Esso Fuel, Evri, Waves, Inkjet, Halfords Motoring Club, Tesco surveys and international calling. Points will also not be awarded for **non-qualifying products**.

cards.title: In pictures: Snow hits the UK as cold blast sees temperatures plummet below freezing
cards.abstract: In pictures: Snow hits the UK as cold blast sees temperatures plummet below freezing - When will it next snow?

images.title: Winter weather Jan 8th 2024
images.caption: Winter weather Jan 8th 2024

topQuestions.q: How does the yellow warning for ice affect the flood recovery efforts in the UK?
What are the health risks and impacts of the amber cold health alert for several regions?

highlights.text: The article reports on ***snow and cold weather*** in the UK, with people in **London and the south east** waking up to *ice, sleet and cold showers* on Monday. **Temperatures dipped to -8C** at Altnaharra in the Scottish Highlands, and are expected to be **below average for this time of year** for much of the week. The **Met Office** issued a **yellow warning** for ice across *southern England and South Wales*, which will last from Monday to Tuesday, and advised people to plan their travel routes and check for delays and road closures. An **amber cold health alert** is also in place for several regions until Friday, meaning **cold weather impacts are likely to be felt across the whole health service** for an extended period of time. The article also reminds readers of the recent **Storm Henk** and the ongoing **flood recovery** efforts, and quotes the **Environment Agency** and the **Government** on their actions and plans to protect homes and communities. The article warns that **Tuesday night could be even colder** by potentially dropping to *-9C* in the Scottish Highlands, while daytime temperatures are not expected to top *6C* in the south and *8C* in the north.

cards.title: Spain brings back mask rules as ‘tridemic’ of respiratory illness hits Europe
cards.abstract: During the pandemic, Spain brought in one of the most draconian lockdowns

images.title: Spain brings back mask rules as ‘tridemic’ of respiratory illness hits Europe

highlights.text:
The article explains the decision of ***Spain*** to **make masks compulsory** in *hospitals and health centres* from Wednesday, as part of a **"tridemic"** of flu, respiratory viruses and Covid-19 that has hit Europe after the festive season. It:

- Provides data on the **rise in flu cases** and the **increase in hospital admissions** for Covid-19 in Spain and other European countries, such as the UK, Italy, and Germany, and predicts that the **peak of flu cases** is yet to come.
- Highlights the **challenges faced by hospitals** in coping with the influx of patients and the **need for more staff and resources**.
- Quotes the **Spanish health minister** and other health experts on the **scientific evidence and common sense** behind the mask rule, and the **impact of children returning to school** on the spread of the virus.
- Describes a **proposed system** for workers to take a **"responsible break"** from work of three days without a doctor's certificate if they have a mild illness, to **reduce the burden on doctors** and avoid unnecessary bureaucracy.

cards.title: Two major mortgage lenders announce ‘very significant’ rate cuts
cards.abstract: Two major mortgage lenders announce ‘very significant’ rate cuts - Prospective buyers who feared a mortgage was beyond them could find they are now cheaper than expected

images.title: Britain's mortgage costs rise due to speculation on interest rates increase

highlights.text:
**Mortgage rate cuts by Barclays and Santander**

- Barclays and Santander are the latest lenders to slash mortgage rates, following HSBC and Halifax last week.
- Barclays is launching a two-year fixed mortgage at 4.17 per cent for new home buyers with a 60 per cent loan to value, and cutting rates by up to 0.5 per cent for other products.
- Santander is launching a five-year fixed rate loan at 3.89 per cent for remortgagers and 3.94 per cent for first-time buyers with a 40 per cent deposit, and reducing rates by up to 0.82 per cent for other products.
- Mortgage experts say this is a very significant move and expect more lenders to follow in the coming days, bringing more opportunities to buy a home.

cards.title: Sweden states all citizens must be prepared for war
cards.abstract: There's a threat of war, and all citizens "must act to strengthen the country's defense," according to the Supreme Commander of the Swedish Armed Forces, Micael Bydén, and the Minister for Civil Defence, Carl-Oscar Bohlin. According to Minister Bohlin, the situation is very serious. He has expressed concern that the modernization of civil defense i...

images.title: Illustrative photo (Photo: Getty Images)
images.caption: Illustrative photo (Photo: Getty Images)

topQuestions.q: Why is civil society vital for Sweden's defense and what role can citizens play in it?

highlights.text: The article reports on the joint statement by ***Sweden's Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces***, *Micael Bydén*, and the **Minister for Civil Defence**, *Carl-Oscar Bohlin*, on the need for **all citizens to be prepared for war**. They cite the **serious threat of war** from *Russia* and the **slow pace of civil defense modernization** as reasons for their call. They urge Swedes to **reflect, act, and strengthen the country's defense** by preparing for possible scenarios and supporting the NATO membership process. They stress that **a strong civil society** is vital in such a situation. They also reiterate the **Swedish government's stance on Ukraine** and its military and political support for its fight against Russian aggression.

cards.title: Shoppers face big changes to Clubcard, Nectar and other supermarket loyalty discounts
cards.abstract: A watchdog is looking into two-tier pricing schemes.

images.title: Supermarket loyalty cards
images.caption: Supermarket loyalty pricing is being reviewed by watchdogs (Picture: Getty)

topQuestions.q: What are the benefits and drawbacks of different supermarket loyalty schemes for shoppers and retailers?

highlights.text: The article examines the possible changes to ***supermarket loyalty schemes***, such as **Clubcard** and **Nectar**, following an **investigation by the Competition and Markets Authority (the CMA)**. It explains how retailers like **Boots** and **Tesco** offer **two-tier pricing** to members, where they pay less for certain products, and how this affects **non-members** and **shoppers' ability to compare prices**. It cites a **Which? report** that found some supermarkets used **'potentially dodgy tactics'** to inflate prices before reducing them to make reductions seem more substantial, and how **Tesco** and **Sainsbury's** defended their schemes. It also outlines the CMA's **review process** and its previous findings on **food price inflation and retail competition** in the sector, and how it will ensure that **loyalty card prices do not mislead** and that **certain groups are not excluded** from member-only schemes.

cards.title: Blunt haircuts are about to be everywhere in 2024 – here's how to choose your style
cards.abstract: Make it polished & razor sharp this year

highlights.text:
The article explains what a ***blunt haircut*** is and how it can suit different hair types and styles. It covers:

- The definition and benefits of a **blunt cut**, which is *bold and sharp* rather than soft and feathery, and creates a *polished and uniform look* that falls into place easily.
- The suitability of a **blunt cut** for most hair types and lengths, especially *short hair* and *curly hair*, and the factors to consider before choosing this style, such as hair thickness and movement.
- The examples of **blunt hair inspiration** from celebrities and Instagram users, showing how a blunt cut can look chic and snappy with various hair types and lengths.
- The **styling products** that can enhance a blunt cut, such as sprays, mists, and creams, and how to apply them for optimal results.

cards.title: Why you shouldn't drink coffee in the first hour of waking up
cards.abstract: Caffeine and cortisol don't mix.

images.title: plus size Woman Sitting on Her Bed and Drinking Tea
images.caption: Give it an hour after you wake up (Picture: Getty Images)

topQuestions.q: How does cortisol affect our mood and energy levels throughout the day?
What are the potential risks of drinking too much coffee for our health and well-being?
What are the benefits of turmeric lattes and chicory root 'coffee' over regular coffee?

highlights.text:
**Best time to drink coffee**: Wait at least an hour after waking up to drink coffee, as cortisol levels are high in the morning and caffeine may counteract its alertness effect and increase tolerance.

**Effects of caffeine on sleep**: Caffeine blocks the sleep-promoting chemical adenosine, which builds up throughout the day and makes us feel sleepy. Drinking too much coffee can interfere with falling asleep and reduce sleep quality.

**Caffeine-free alternatives**: Turmeric lattes, chicory root 'coffee', peppermint and ginger tea are some of the hot drinks that can offer health benefits without caffeine. They can help with digestion, headaches, nausea, inflammation and sleep deprivation.

cards.title: Forget your tumble dryer — Duux's new smart dehumidifier will dry wet laundry in hours
cards.abstract: Introducing the Bora Smart 20L Dehumidifier...

topQuestions.q: How does Duux's smart dehumidifier work to dry wet laundry?

highlights.text: The article introduces the ***Bora Smart 20L Dehumidifier*** by *Duux*, a smart device that **efficiently dries wet laundry in a room** at a lower cost than a tumble dryer. The product can **remove up to 20 litres of water in 24 hours**, making it ideal for every room in the home. It is **easy to control** with the *Duux Smart app*, *Amazon Alexa*, *Google Assistant*, or the *LED panel*. It is also **quiet** at only 36dB, and has a **built-in hygrostat and carbon filter** that regulate the humidity and remove odours. The product costs **£299.99** and is available from *Duux* and some major UK retailers.

cards.title: 'Historic win for animals': South Korea bans sale and production of dog meat
cards.abstract: Some dog farmers plan to challenge the upcoming ban on production and sales of dog meat. View on euronews

images.title: South Korea plans to ban the consumption of dog meat by the end of the year
images.caption: Dogs are seen in a cage at a dog farm in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, 27 June 2023.

topQuestions.q: How will the ban affect the dog meat industry and its workers in South Korea?

highlights.text:
**Dog meat ban in South Korea**

- South Korea's parliament passed a bill to ban the production and sale of dog meat for human consumption from 2027, with a grace period of three years for the industry to transition.
- The bill was supported by the majority of the public, especially the younger generations, and the first lady, but opposed by some dog farmers who plan to challenge it in court.
- The bill aims to respect animal rights and promote a harmonious co-existence between humans and animals, as dog meat consumption is seen as an ancient and cruel practice by many.

cards.title: Unique Japanese airport built in middle of sea starts sinking
cards.abstract: Kansai International Airport, located on artificial islands in the middle of Osaka Bay in Japan, is slowly sinking underwater. Some experts believe that it may cease to exist by 2056. Sources used: The Daily Express, Kansai Airports, and Wikipedia. Where is Kansai Airport located? Kansai International Airport (Kansai Airport) is a Japanese private ...

images.title: Unique Japanese airport (photo: Getty Images)
images.caption: Unique Japanese airport (photo: Getty Images)

highlights.text:
The article explains the history and current state of ***Kansai International Airport***, a private international airport on artificial islands in *Osaka Bay* in Japan. It:

- Describes the construction of the airport from **1994 to 2007**, costing over *$20 billion*, and the challenges of building on unstable soil and against natural hazards.
- Highlights the airport's ability to withstand **earthquakes and typhoons** over time, and its gradual **sinking into the water** due to the subsidence of the islands.
- States that the airport is currently **12 meters underwater** and may sink faster at the edges, reaching a height of *4 meters* above water before flooding stops, which is expected by **2056**.

cards.title: Why it seems like everyone is sick right now — and it’s not down to Covid
cards.abstract: Why it seems like everyone is sick right now — and it’s not down to Covid

slides.body: As if January wasn’t miserable enough, the harsh weather conditions mean coughs, colds, and viruses are running rampant among us. Along with your typical colds and flu, we also still have Covid to worry about — but have you noticed anything different this year? Namely, the fact that literally everyone seems to be getting ill right now? (Picture: Getty Images)

image.title: Why it seems like everyone is sick right now — and it’s not down to Covid
image.caption: As if January wasn’t miserable enough, the harsh weather conditions mean coughs, colds, and viruses are running rampant among us. Along with your typical colds and flu, we also still have Covid to worry about — but have you noticed anything different this year? Namely, the fact that literally everyone seems to be getting ill right now? (Picture: Getty Images)

slides.body: And not just that, but also a lot of us are feeling a lot more rotten than usual. The good news is, its probably not Covid — but here comes the bad news. It turns out it’s possible to have multiple flus and viruses at the same time. Dr Chris Smith, a virologist from the University of Cambridge, made the revelation during a recent interview with the BBC (Picture: Getty Images)

image.title: Why it seems like everyone is sick right now — and it’s not down to Covid
image.caption: And not just that, but also a lot of us are feeling a lot more rotten than usual. The good news is, its probably not Covid — but here comes the bad news. It turns out it’s possible to have multiple flus and viruses at the same time. Dr Chris Smith, a virologist from the University of Cambridge, made the revelation during a recent interview with the BBC (Picture: Getty Images)

slides.body: ‘We occasionally see people who are diagnosed with two, sometimes three, viral infections simultaneously,’ he told the outlet. So, if you or a loved one had an ‘awful cold’ over the festive season that just wouldn’t quit, Dr Smith says it likely that you may have ‘succumbed to several things either all at the same time or one after another like a domino effect' (Picture: Getty Images)

images.title: Why it seems like everyone is sick right now — and it’s not down to Covid
images.caption: As if January wasn’t miserable enough, the harsh weather conditions mean coughs, colds, and viruses are running rampant among us. Along with your typical colds and flu, we also still have Covid to worry about — but have you noticed anything different this year? Namely, the fact that literally everyone seems to be getting ill right now? (Picture: Getty Images)

Why is it more eco-friendly to use a dehumidifier than a tumble dryer to dry clothes?

highlights.text: The article explains how to use a ***dehumidifier*** to dry clothes efficiently and cheaply, especially in winter when energy bills are high. It cites **Martin Lewis**, the MoneySavingExpert, who recommends using a dehumidifier instead of a tumble dryer, as they can **halve the drying times** and cost **around 7p per hour** to run. It also highlights the benefits of using a dehumidifier for **allergy sufferers**, as it can **neutralise harmful bacteria** and **freshen the air**. It reviews two models of dehumidifiers that have a **laundry mode** that can adjust the fan speed and power to dry a range of items quickly and quietly. The article provides links to buy the models and vouchers for more discounts.

cards.title: Signs of brain tumor: Doctor names main symptoms
cards.abstract: Brain tumors can be malignant or benign, primary or secondary, but in all cases, the sooner treatment begins, the better. Family doctor Kateryna Pinchuk explained how to timely identify this problem. Sources used in writing the material: Kateryna Pinchuk's Instagram page, Wikipedia. When to do CT and MRI According to the doctor, it is necessary to ...

images.caption: Illustrative photo (Freepik)

highlights.text:
**Brain tumors: types and treatment**

- Brain tumors can be either malignant or benign, primary or secondary. Malignant tumors are cancerous, while benign tumors are not. Primary tumors start in the brain, while secondary tumors spread from other parts of the body.
- The sooner treatment begins, the better. Treatment options depend on the type, size and location of the tumor, as well as the patient's age and health condition.
- Headaches are a common symptom of brain tumors, but not the only one. Other symptoms include dizziness, loss of consciousness, nausea, vomiting, behavior changes, speech problems, paralysis, double vision and weight loss.
- If you have any of these symptoms, do not ignore them or self-medicate. Consult a doctor and get a CT or MRI scan to diagnose the problem. Early detection can save your life.

cards.title: IKEA's smart sensors are now available to buy – and they're impressively affordable
cards.abstract: IKEA’s new sensors will alert you to doors and windows being opened, and to movement inside or outside your home.

topQuestions.q: How do IKEA's smart sensors work and what can they control?

highlights.text:
**IKEA launches new smart sensors**

- IKEA has released two new smart sensors, the Parasoll and the Vallhorn, that can monitor your home and alert you to various issues via the IKEA Home smart app.
- The Parasoll is a door and window sensor that can detect when they are opened or closed, and can also control smart lighting devices.
- The Vallhorn is a motion sensor that can activate up to 10 connected smart lights when movement is detected, and has adjustable settings for day and night modes.
- The Badring is a water leakage sensor that will be available from April 2024, and can reduce the impact of water damage incidents by alerting you to leaks via the app or a built-in siren.
